column6: Description

Supports building owners in the residential apartment building and accommodation sector to undertake environmental ratings, certifications, audits and assessments for existing buildings to be resource efficient and achieve net zero emissions by 2035.

Funding can support:
- NABERS, Green Star Performance or EarthCheck assessment and/or certification
- residential energy/water/waste assessments
- renewables/electrification feasibility assessments
- net zero action plans.
column9:
(From historical information) between about $2,500 to $15,000 maximum

For perspective, the total budget for 2023/24 was $400,000. Total of 24 eligible applications for the allications.
(https://meetings.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/documents/s74064/Grants%20and%20Sponsorship%20-%20Environmental%20Grants.pdf)
column10:
Assessment criteria:
- evidence of the need for the project and proposed outcomes
- capacity and experience of the applicant to deliver the project
- demonstrated connection and benefit to the local area and community
- evidence of diversity, inclusion and equity in the planning and delivery of the project
- how the project delivers against the funding priorities.

Questions asked in application during assessment stage:
- Why is there a need for the project and what are the proposed outcomes?
- What is your experience in delivering projects?
- How does the project rate against the funding priorities?
column15:
Next applications open and close in early 2025; recommendations to Council in June 2025

The program was implemented in previous years (as early as 2023/24). List of past grant recipients for the green building grant: https://www.cityofsydney.nsw.gov.au/research-reports/approved-grants

column6:
Free expert advice to reduce energy and water use in apartment buildings.

Each participating strata plan receives:
- energy and water assessments – NABERS rating
- an energy action plan with recommended improvements
- a presentation on NABERS ratings and energy action plans
- tailored advice on improving waste management and recycling
- a WaterFix program by Sydney Water, if the building meets certain criteria
- access to webinars, resources and opportunities to connect with people in other buildings through our leadership network.
column10:
Selected by application. Buildings will be chosen based on:
- capacity and commitment to improve environmental performance and resilience
- potential for making big savings – we’ll consider issues like the size and complexity of your building, and the amount of energy and water consumed.
column14:
- The Council has worked with 270 buildings, including 16,407 apartments.
- On average, the Council has identified that buildings can reduce their energy use by 30%.
- Since 2016, participants have saved $9,664,904 in energy and water bills.

column4: Passed motion for new homes and businesses to be all-electric.
column6:
On 23 August 2023, the Council passed a motion to ban gas in new homes and businesses in the LGA. 

This will involve inserting new clauses into the council’s planning rules to require new homes and businesses to include electric appliances like stoves, cooktops, heaters and hot water units, instead of gas ones.
column14:
Research by 350 Australia shows that the ban could cut carbon emissions across the LGA by 1.7 million tonnes over the 40 year life of a dwelling.

https://www.governmentnews.com.au/councils-throw-down-gauntlet-to-state-government-over-gas-ban/

column6:
New and revised provisions in respect of:
- Thermal Safety - requiring high-performance glazing for windows and skylights, ceiling fans in all habitable rooms, vegetation for cooling and light-coloured roofs
- Indoor Air Quality - preventing the installation of gas stoves, gas ovens and gas space heating in residential development. This will also enable these developments to reach net zero greenhouse gas emissions.
- Uptake for Electric Vehicles - requiring certain new developments to include EV charging and or supporting power infrastructure
- Transition to Low Emissions living - requiring all homes to include designs for future all electric capacity and power by renewable energy.
- Sustainability performance of office buildings, shops, hotels, aged care and retirement living - requiring improved energy and water ratings and commitment agreements under the National Built Environment Rating Scheme (NABERS)
- Cooling and shading of neighbourhoods by strengthening protection for existing tree canopy on private land.
- Running costs through ensuring energy efficiency measures that reduce energy demand.

On 7 December 2022, Waverley Council implemented changes to its Development Control Plan to require new residential buildings be fitted with all-electric indoor appliances (cooktops, ovens and internal space heaters) to improve indoor air quality and local health outcomes.

Building Futures is a free Council program to help large buildings (25+ apartments or commercial lots) to save money on their energy and water bills and improve environmental performance. Participating buildings work towards reducing common area energy use by 20%, reducing operating costs and greenhouse emissions.

Successful applicants receive:
- Energy assessments of common areas, costed recommendations and implementation support
- Up to $1000 matched funding towards one or more implemented efficiency upgrades
- A rooftop solar assessment
- Assessment of water consumption through Sydney Water’s WaterFix program
- Access to Waverley Council’s apartment recycling resources
column10:
To be eligible for Building Futures, buildings must be:
- Strata titled or deposited plan (residential or non-residential)
- 25+ apartments or commercial lots
- Located in the Waverley Local Government Area

column6:
As part of a 12-month trial, apartment buildings in Waverley can receive up to $5,000 total in rebates for undertaking:
- common area energy assessments (including energy audit, electric vehicle feasibility, solar feasibility and NABERS for Apartment Buildings ratings): 50% up to $1,000  
- installing rooftop solar: 20% rebate up to $4,000
- electrifying centralised hot water systems: 20% rebate up to $4,000 
- electrifying swimming pool heating systems: 20% rebate up to $1,000 for pool or spa gas to electric
column10: Must be apartment buildings in the Waverley LGA

column6: Free 30 minute online consultation with an independent rooftop solar expert.
column10: Applicants are required to submit a form which will require a copy of the strata electricity bill and photos of the electricity meter. Consultations require at least two strata committee members and/or building managers.
column15: Available in Randwick, Waverley and Woollahra.

column6: Free 30 minute online consultation with an independent rooftop solar expert.
column10: Applicants are required to submit a form which will require a copy of the strata electricity bill and photos of the electricity meter. Consultations require at least two strata committee members and/or building managers.
column15: Available in Randwick, Waverley and Woollahra.

column6: Free 30 minute online consultation with an independent rooftop solar expert.
column10: Applicants are required to submit a form which will require a copy of the strata electricity bill and photos of the electricity meter. Consultations require at least two strata committee members and/or building managers.

column6: Rebate for installation of electric vehicle charger at home.
column9:
Rebate:
- Household: 25% up to $250
- Apartment Block: 25% up to $5,000
- Business: 25% up to $1,000
column10:
- Only available for properties in the Randwick Local Government Area.
- Must be an electric vehicle charger (or electric vehicle infrastructure in apartment blocks).
- Must be installed by a licenced electrician.
- Installed within the past 12 months.
- Not required for BASIX or Development Application Compliance purposes.
column14:
"As of 30 June 2021, 263 rebates have been provided to the community, costing Council
approximately $150,000. An additional $1.5 million of investment has been leveraged from the
community for energy and water saving initiatives. The rebates have resulted in 6 energy
assessments, 5 hot water systems, 29 insulation installations, 606 LEDs upgraded across 27
properties, 13 rainwater tanks, 157 rooftop solar and 16 battery installations, and more. Rooftop
solar has been of key interest to the community, with a total of 1,300 kW of solar being
installed.

The impact of the Sustainability Rebates is estimated at savings of 1,600 megawatt-hours of
electricity, 1,400 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent, 800 kilolitres of water, and $250,000 in
electricity bills each year. Surveyed recipients found that 100% would recommend the program
to other residents and over 75% of residents have stated that the rebate had a ‘high’ or ‘very
high’ impact on their decision to move ahead with their particular energy or water saving
purchase or installation."

(Local Government NSW report: https://lgnsw.org.au/common/Uploaded%20files/Environment_Awards/2021/Randwick_sustainability_rebates.pdf)

column6: Rebate for Residential Efficiency Scorecard Assessments (and other general energy assessment) for the purpose of knowing where/how to reduce energy use.

- For Apartment Blocks: includes NABERS Ratings, electric vehicle charging assessments and solar assessments.

column6: Rebate for hot water system. Also eligible for the Federal Government's STC rebate and the State Government's ESC rebate when installing an electric heat pump or rooftop solar hot water system.

column6: Broadly supports energy and environmental sustainability within the objectives of its Development Control Plan at page 25. The DCP provides general guidelines/principles.
Canada Bay Council subscribes to SunSpot to provide residents with assistance on the type of solar panel suited to their house.

column6: Limited number of free Solar Feasibility and Energy Assessments available for apartments blocks, to identify what energy saving measures suit their buildings.
column10:
To be eligible for this program, applicants must:
- Be located in the City of Canada Bay Council area.
- Commit to implementing energy saving measures equivalent to the audit value that is paid by Council to Wattblock (between $1000 - $3,500) within 1 year of receiving the report.
- Commit to participating in a Council run case study.

Buildings will be selected on the basis of their:
- Energy consumption.
- Size and complexity.
- Capacity of owners corporations to implement upgrades.
- Online application
column14: Canada Bay Council has supported more than 10 apartment buildings with energy and sustainability assessments since 2019.
column15:
Applicants require a written approval from their strata committee to participate in the program and a current copy of their energy bills.

Limited spaces are available for this program.

column4: Passed motion for new homes and businesses to be all-electric.
column6: On 19 September 2023, the Council unanimously passed the motion to ban gas cooking and space heating applicances in new buildings in Canada Bay.
column14:
Research by Strategy Policy Research shows that this policy could save 344,343 tonnes of carbon emissions within Canada Bay LGA compared with business as usual over 40 years. It could also save new households an average of $432 per year in energy bills (about $5,500 over a 40-year life of a dwelling) which amounts to $44.9 million for all new homes across the LGA.

https://350.org.au/files/2023/08/Analysis_-City-of-Sydney-ban-on-new-gas-connections-3.pdf

column6: The Council has two thermal imaging cameras available for residents to borrow at no charge from the Green Living Centre.

Power-Mates can be borrowed free of charge from the Green Living Centre and can be used to monitor the energy consumption of different appliances in your home. The Power-Mate will even estimate the average costs of running the appliance over the year, both in dollar value and in terms of greenhouse gas emissions.

Council is supporting apartments and townhouses (strata) to go solar. The focus is to support the 75 strata properties who have received a Council funded independent solar feasibility study in 2021-2022 to progress to solar installation.

The program involves:
- A free solar feasibility assessment conducted by independent industry specialists
- A detailed report which clearly illustrates the environmental and financial case for rooftop solar
- Phone/online video conferencing support at strata meetings, if requested, to help communicate the benefits
column10: Targeted towards strata residents, committee members, strata managers, building or facilities managers.

column6: In August 2023, the Council banned gas applicances in residential premises.

column15:
Burwood Council 'promotes' that its residents switch to a GreenPower electricity plan.

column6: Rebate of up to $500 to residents for installing solar photovoltaic (solar PV) on residential properties in Canterbury-Bankstown. This initiative is part of Council’s target to increase rooftop solar on single unit dwellings to 50% by 2036 and to support residents choosing renewable solar energy for their homes.
column10:
- The applicant property must be located within the Canterbury-Bankstown Local Government Area.
- The applicant property must not have an existing solar PV system installed.
- The applicant must either be the owner or landlord of the property and the applicant can only apply for a rebate for one property.
- The installer for the solar PV system must be accredited by Solar Accreditation Australia (SAA) and the installation must be carried out by a licensed electrician and meet all relevant installation standards. You can check for your installer's SAA accreditation here. 
- Properties under a strata scheme are not eligible.
- The solar PV system installed must be new and must not have been previously used - Solar PV systems installed before the launch of the Solar Rebate program on 15 June 2023 are not eligible.
- To apply for the rebate, your solar PV must have been installed within the last 3 months of applying for the rebate.
column12: N/A - available until funding is exhausted
column15:
No pre-approvals required.

Retrospective rebate applications beyond 3 months from the date of application are not available.

The Council recommends requesting a minimum of three quotes from an installation company on the New Energy Tech Consumer Code (NETCC) list of New Energy Tech Approved Sellers: https://www.newenergytech.org.au/find-an-approved-seller

column6: Georges River Council participates in the Our Energy Future program, which focuses on building the capacity of community groups to disseminate information about solar panels and energy efficiency opportunities for households.

column4: Save Power Kit and Thermal Cameras
column6: Save Power Kits can help residents find out which of their appliances are using the most energy. Thermal Cameras can help locate insulation and draught problems in homes.

At its 14 August 2024 Council meeting, Hornsby Shire Council voted unanimously to adopt changes to its Development Control Plan to ensure that new homes built in the LGA are to be fitted with electric indoor appliances (cooktops, heaters and ovens).

The rebates are designed to support apartment blocks.

Rebates (50% of cost):
- Smart enabled shared electric car charging station or Infrastructure to support individual charging points to a minimum 5 residential parking lots (eg. upgrade of distribution board and cable infrastructure) - maximum $2,000
- Shared solar PV connected to a minimum of 8 residential units - maximum $4,000
- Replacement of centralised gas hot water system with heat-pump hot water system - maximum $2,000
- Energy efficiency upgrades in common areas as recommended by a mandatory Level 2 energy audit (eg. LED lighting, ventilation, pool pump upgrades, solar PV etc.) - maximum $4,000
column15: The program offers a maximum of $60,00 in rebates to apartment blocks. Applications open until funds are exhausted.

column6: $250 rebates available for Ku-ring-gai residents who replace existing inefficient, single-speed pool pumps with an energy efficient pool pump (6-star rated and above as listed by Greenhouse & Energy Minimum Standards Regulator).
column15:
- Applicants will have 21 days from when written pre-approval is provided by Council to complete installation and return the required paperwork (or by 25 June 2025 - whichever is earlier).
- Properties that have received a pool pump in the past are not eligible to apply again.
- Rebates are only available for replacement of single speed pool pumps that are used for general filtration.

Pre-approval for the pump is required.

column4: Energy and Solar Expert Advisory Service
column6: The energy and solar experts can provide advice to help Northern Beaches households and businesses improve energy efficiency, install solar and reduce carbon emissions. In the free 20-minute phone conversation/appointment, the experts can discuss energy efficiency, solar (including solar for strata), solar batteries, electrification, EV charging.
column15: Free 20-minute phone conversations on Mondays from 5-7pm and Tuesdays from 9-11am (except on public holidays).

column6: Residents can borrow a thermal camera from from Willoughby City Library in Chatswood. The camera can be loaned out to residents with a current full Willoughby City Council Library membership, for a period of 3 weeks. The thermal camera can be used to identify warm or cold air leaks into homes, such as gaps around windows, doors and insulation (walls, ceiling, floor).
Council has partnered with a reputable solar power supplier to provide residents with quality solar power and battery products at a preferential Willoughby City Council price.

column6: Free Council initiative to assist apartment buildings and strata schemes reduce their energy and water use and save money. This involves receiving independent expert advice.

column6: At its 21 September 2023 Council meeting, Lave Cove Council passed new planning rules which prohibit the installation of gas appliances in all new development (residential and non-residential)

column4: The Mosman Apartment and Strata Savings Program (Strata sustainability program)
column6:
Free independent advice to eligible residential apartment buildings to help improve sustainability, reduce greenhouse gas emissions and cut expenses.

The program offers – at no cost:
- Energy assessments performed by industry specialists.
- Detailed reports which will clearly illustrate the financial case for upgrades.
- Online video call support at strata meetings if requested to help communicate benefits of building upgrades.
- General support.
column10: The scheme offers sustainability assessments and reports to larger strata schemes and aged care facilities.

column6:
There are fourteen rebates that can be applied for as part of the program up to the value of $5,000.

They include: 
- rooftop solar
- rooftop solar health check
- home battery
- electric vehicle charger
- hot water heat pumps
- reverse cycle air conditioners for heating
- induction cook top
- business kitchen electrification
- insulation
- rainwater tanks
- waterfix program
- lighting
- pool pump
- level 2 energy audit
column10: Sustainable Product must have been installed or undertaken 12 months from the date listed on final invoice.

column6:
For strata buildings of two units or more, Council offers the following at no cost:
- energy assessments performed by industry specialists
- detailed reports which will clearly illustrate the financial case for upgrades
- attendance at strata meetings if requested to help communicate benefits of building upgrades
- workshops and information sessions for apartment residents
- upgrade opportunities (including solar electricity, solar sharing to multiple units, batteries, heat pumps, LED lighting with smart controls, EV charging and carpark ventilation)

The Council is part of the Our Energy Future program. Our Energy Future provides impartial, up-to-date energy efficiency and renewable energy advice and support for households, businesses and City of Parramatta staff.

column4: Hawkesbury City Council Net Zero Emissions and Water Efficiency Strategy
column6: On 31 March 2021, the Council adopted the Strategy. New community emissions target was adopted by Council on 28 September 2021. Council’s newly adopted community emissions target is Net Zero Emissions by 2030. The strategy outlines a plan to guide Council, and the community to achieve emission and water reduction across Council’s operations and the broader LGA.

The Council has partnered with the Australian Energy Foundation to provide solar/insulation installation and advice to residents - accessed directly with AEF rather than through the Council. 
(Information is vague)

Residents can book a 45-minute one-on-one energy advice consultation with Ian Moxon (an experienced sustainability consultant). Held at Penrith City Library (2 Sep 2024) and St Marys Library.

Ian Moxon provides information on:
- Reading bill and finding the best retailer
- Home energy efficiencies
- Solar power and batteries
- Electric Vehicles
- All-electric homes

column4: Be Energy Efficient at Home and Save Money Webinar
column6:
A free webinar that covers: 
- New technologies around energy-efficient appliances, smart home systems, and renewable energy solutions that revolutionize the way we power homes
- Practical methods, expert tips and simple techniques to maximize energy efficiency in every aspect of your home: hot water, lighting, insulation, heating and cooling systems.
- Immediate cost savings by comparing retail energy plans which can lead to substantial savings.
- Understand the various supplies of energy that we commonly use at home and how these fuels impact our family's health 
- Rebates and other government support that will help households unlock new and efficient energy saving products.

Residents can borrow a Home Energy Efficiency Kit to:
- show what appliances are using the most power in the home
- help identify issues that are affecting the energy efficiency of the home
- give ideas and steps to take to save money and power

column4: Passed motion for new homes and businesses to be all-electric.
column6: On 26 September 2023, the Council passed a motion to start the process requiring new homes and businesses across the municipality to be all-electric and gas-free. The motion will explore new planning laws to require new homes and businesses, including apartments, to include electric appliances like stoves, cooktops, heaters and hot water units, instead of gas ones.
column14: New household would save an average of $432 per year on their energy bills. This equates to more than $5,500 in today’s dollars over a typical 40-year life of a dwelling, totalling $16.6 million across the Blue Mountains LGA.

column6: The Council has partnered with partner with Good for the Hood to present the "@HOME" program, an initiative designed to promote smart, sustainable actions that residents can take within their homes.

column4: Various initiatives by the Council's Sustainability Unit
column6:
The Council's Sustainability Unit offers:
- energy audits of their home, community facility or business.
- workshops on subjects such as being more energy efficient.
- visits to educational facilities to participate in activities about being energy smart.
- financial incentives for energy smart products and initiatives (subject to change and conditions).

Minimal details available.

column4: Education and behaviour change program (one of its Cities Power Partnership pledges)
column6:
In 2020, the Council resolved to participate in Cities Power Partnership. One of its pledges was to "implement an education and behaviour change program to influence the behaviour of Council officers, local residents and businesses within the Local Government Area (LGA) to drive the shift to renewable energy, energy efficiency and sustainable transport."

The Council does not seem to have any substantive education program in place further to the information available on its website.

column4: Rebates (part of its Cities Power Partnership pledge)
column6:
The Council promotes state government programs to support community access to rebates for actions that improve energy efficiency in the home. This includes showerhead exchanges, fridge buybacks and current Appliance Replacement Offer program.

Minimal details available.

Council is offering a subsidised Residential Efficiency Scorecard assessment. A government-accredited Scorecard assessor provides an energy rating for the home and a plan for ways to make improvements.
column9:
Subsidy for energy efficiency rating assessment.

Successful applicants will be eligible for a personalised Scorecard assessment for only $50 (assessments are normally valued at $500-$600 depending on the size of home).
column10:
The Terms and Conditions provide that:

- Entry is open to Lake Macquarie Residents that own a home within Lake Macquarie City. Entrants must be over 18 years of age. Lake Macquarie City Council employees and immediate families are eligible to enter.
- Successful applicants will be chosen at random via a lottery system

column6: Residents can borrow the Home Energy Audit Toolkit from the 'Library of things' to assess the energy efficiency of their home applicances.

column4: Partnership with Lismore Community Sustainability Forum
column6: The Council partnered with the Lismore Community Sustainability Forum (LCSF), a group of volunteers dedicated to sustainable living, to design and deliver community education on energy efficiency in the home. Energy consultants audited household energy use and ran ‘kitchen table’ neighbourhood workshops to build social networks, share information and support participants to make changes.
column13: Lismore City Council; Lismore Community Sustainability Forum
column14:
A survey of the 50 plus participants before and after the project showed a marked improvement in knowledge.
“It was the little things I learnt that made the biggest difference to saving energy,” said one participant.

column6: The Council hosted a pop-up stall in one of the shopping centres in the LGA to help residents reduce energy usage to save money.
The Council partnered with an expert from Your Energy Friend to present a webinar series on sustainable energy use.
Shellharbour City Council's Sustainability Rebates Program assists homeowners and landlords to electrify their homes.
column9:
Rooftop solar: 10% up to $500

Heat pump water heater: 10% up to $500

Induction cooktop: 10% up to $250

Electric vehicle chargers: 10% up to $250

Home battery: 5% up to $500
column14: In 2023/24, the Council's Small Environmental Projects Fund (SEPF) provided 60 rebates to eligible homeowners and landlords for the installation of sustainability products as part of the Sustainability Rebates Program.

column6:
Residents can borrow the Energy Efficiency Toolkit from the library to test the energy efficiency of homes applicances. 

The toolkit includes: 
- Energy saving thermometer
- Energy meter
- Water flow measuring cup
- Non-contact thermometer
Residents can borrow the toolkit by contacting the council and arranging for collection from the civic centre.
The Council partnered with an expert from Your Energy Friend to host a workshop on sustainable energy use.

column4: Sustainability and Climate Action Plan and Sustainable Energy Strategy - target of rooftop solar on 33% of all dwellings by 2025.
column6: Target of rooftop solar on 33% of all dwellings by 2025.

Energy and Water Saving Kits available for hire from library for free.

Each kit contains:  
1- 0 Amp powermate to help measure power consumption and running costs
- non-contact thermometer to help assess surfaces and appliances
- water flow measuring cup to assess water usage
- guide to assist in calculating your energy and water use.
Save Power Kits available for borrowing from library.
Save Power Kits available for borrowing from library.
In 2013, the Council coordinated the Parkes Shire Solar Communities program that led to in excess of 300 households installing rooftop solar at highly competitive prices.
column14: The Parkes Shire area at the time becoming one of the highest per capita adopters of roof top solar in NSW in 2013.
